revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} [[File:Air pollution by industrial chimneys.jpg|thumb|Before flue gas desulfurization was installed, the emissions from this power plant in [[New Mexico]] contained a significant amount of sulfur dioxide.]] [[File:G_G_Allen_Steam_Plant,_scrubber.JPG|thumb|upright|The [[G. G. Allen Steam Station]] scrubber]] '''Flue-gas desulfurization''' ('''FGD''') is a set of technologies used to remove [[sulfur dioxide]] ({{chem|SO|2}}) from [[Flue-gas emissions from fossil-fuel combustion|exhaust flue gases of fossil-fuel power plant]]s, and from the emissions of other sulfur oxide emitting processes (e.g [[trash incineration]])
==Methods== As stringent environmental regulations regarding SO<sub>2</sub> emissions have been enacted in many countries, {{chem|SO|2}} is now being removed from flue gases by a variety of methods. Below are common methods used:
*[[Wet scrubber|Wet scrubbing]] using a slurry of alkaline [[sorbent]], usually [[limestone]] or [[lime (mineral)|lime]], or seawater to scrub gases; *[[Spray drying|Spray-dry]] scrubbing using similar sorbent slurries; *[[Wet sulfuric acid process]] recovering [[sulfur]] in the form of commercial quality [[sulfuric acid]]; *[[SNOX process|SNOX Flue gas desulfurization]] removes sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulates from flue gases; *Dry sorbent injection systems that introduce powdered hydrated lime (or other sorbent material) into exhaust ducts to eliminate SO2 and SO3 from process emissions.<ref>http://www.nol-tec.com/documents/pdfs/NTS_FGD_02_09_B.pdf</ref>
For a typical coal-fired power station, flue-gas desulfurization (FGD) may remove 90 percent or more of the {{chem|SO|2}} in the flue gases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.compositech-filters.com/power-exhaust-filters|title=Flue Gas Desulfurization - FGD Wastewater Treatment {{!}} Compositech Filters Manufacturer|last=Inc.|first=Compositech Products Manufacturing,|website=www.compositech-filters.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-30}}</ref>
==History== Methods of removing [[sulfur dioxide]] from boiler and furnace exhaust gases have been studied for over 150 years. Early ideas for flue gas desulfurization were established in [[England]] around 1850.
With the construction of large-scale power plants in England in the 1920s, the problems associated with large volumes of {{chem|SO|2}} from a single site began to concern the public. The {{chem|SO|2}} emissions problem did not receive much attention until 1929, when the [[House of Lords]] upheld the claim of a landowner against the Barton Electricity Works of the [[Manchester Corporation]] for damages to his land resulting from {{chem|SO|2}} emissions. Shortly thereafter, a press campaign was launched against the erection of power plants within the confines of London. This outcry led to the imposition of {{chem|SO|2}} controls on all such power plants.<ref name=Biondo>{{cite journal |last1=Biondo |first1=S.J. |last2=Marten |first2=J.C. |title=A History of Flue Gas Desulphurization Systems Since 1850 |journal=Journal of the Air Pollution Control Association |volume=27 |issue=10 |pages=948–61 |date=October 1977}}</ref>
The first major FGD unit at a utility was installed in 1931 at [[Battersea Power Station]], owned by [[London Power Company]]. In 1935, an FGD system similar to that installed at Battersea went into service at Swansea Power Station. The third major FGD system was installed in 1938 at [[Fulham Power Station]]. These three early large-scale FGD installations were abandoned during [[World War II]]. Large-scale FGD units did not reappear at utilities until the 1970s, where most of the installations occurred in the [[United States]] and [[Japan]].<ref name=Biondo/>
As of June 1973, there were 42 FGD units in operation, 36 in Japan and 6 in the United States, ranging in capacity from 5 [[Megawatt|MW]] to 250 MW.<ref name=Beychok>Beychok, Milton R., ''Coping With SO<sub>2</sub>'', Chemical Engineering/Deskbook Issue, 21 October 1974</ref> As of around 1999 and 2000, FGD units were being used in 27 countries, and there were 678 FGD units operating at a total power plant capacity of about 229 [[gigawatts]]. About 45% of the FGD capacity was in the U.S., 24% in [[Germany]], 11% in Japan, and 20% in various other countries. Approximately 79% of the units, representing about 199 gigawatts of capacity, were using lime or limestone wet scrubbing. About 18% (or 25 gigawatts) utilized spray-dry scrubbers or sorbent injection systems.<ref name=BW>Nolan, Paul S., ''Flue Gas Desulfurization Technologies for Coal-Fired Power Plants'', The Babcock & Wilcox Company, U.S., presented by Michael X. Jiang at the Coal-Tech 2000 International Conference, November 2000, Jakarta, Indonesia</ref><ref name=CMU>{{cite journal |first1=Edward S. |last1=Rubin |first2=Sonia |last2=Yeh |first3=David A. |last3=Hounshell |first4=Margaret R. |last4=Taylor |year=2004 |title=Experience curves for power plant emission control technologies |journal=International Journal of Energy Technology and Policy |volume=2 |issue=1–2 |pages=52–69 |url=http://inderscience.metapress.com/content/xrmv74watby1y7e2/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141009182230/http://inderscience.metapress.com/content/xrmv74watby1y7e2/ |archivedate=9 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>Beychok, Milton R., ''Comparative economics of advanced regenerable flue gas desulfurization processes'', EPRI CS-1381, Electric Power Research Institute, March 1980</ref>
==Sulfuric acid mist formation== [[Fossil fuel]]s such as coal and oil can contain a significant amount of sulfur. When fossil fuels are burned, about 95 percent or more of the sulfur is generally converted to [[sulfur dioxide]] ({{chem|SO|2}}). Such conversion happens under normal conditions of temperature and of oxygen present in the [[flue gas]]. However, there are circumstances under which such reaction may not occur.
When flue gas has too much oxygen, the {{chem|SO|2}} further oxidizes into [[sulfur trioxide]] ({{chem|SO|3}}). Too much oxygen is only one of the ways that {{chem|SO|3}} is formed. Gas temperature is also an important factor. At about 800 °C, formation of {{chem|SO|3}} is favored. Another way that {{chem|SO|3}} can be formed is through catalysis by metals in the fuel. Such reaction is particularly true for heavy fuel oil, where a significant amount of [[vanadium]] is present. In whatever way {{chem|SO|3}} is formed, it does not behave like {{chem|SO|2}} in that it forms a liquid [[aerosol]] known as [[sulfuric acid]] ({{chem|H|2|SO|4}}) mist that is very difficult to remove. Generally, about 1% of the sulfur dioxide will be converted to {{chem|SO|3}}. Sulfuric acid mist is often the cause of the blue haze that often appears as the flue gas plume dissipates. Increasingly, this problem is being addressed by the use of wet [[electrostatic precipitator]]s.
== FGD chemistry ==
=== Basic principles === Most FGD systems employ two stages: one for [[fly ash]] removal and the other for {{chem|SO|2}} removal. Attempts have been made to remove both the fly ash and {{chem|SO|2}} in one scrubbing vessel. However, these systems experienced severe maintenance problems and low removal efficiency. In wet scrubbing systems, the flue gas normally passes first through a fly ash removal device, either an electrostatic precipitator or a baghouse, and then into the {{chem|SO|2}}-absorber. However, in dry injection or spray drying operations, the {{chem|SO|2}} is first reacted with the lime, and then the flue gas passes through a particulate control device.
Another important design consideration associated with wet FGD systems is that the flue gas exiting the absorber is saturated with water and still contains some {{chem|SO|2}}. These gases are highly corrosive to any downstream equipment such as fans, ducts, and stacks. Two methods that may minimize corrosion are: (1) reheating the gases to above their [[dew point]], or (2) using materials of construction and designs that allow equipment to withstand the corrosive conditions. Both alternatives are expensive. Engineers determine which method to use on a site-by-site basis.
=== Scrubbing with an alkali solid or solution === [[File:Flue gas desulfurization unit EN.svg|thumb|upright=1.3|Schematic design of the absorber of an FGD]] {{chem|SO|2}} is an [[acid gas]], and, therefore, the typical sorbent slurries or other materials used to remove the {{chem|SO|2}} from the flue gases are alkaline. The reaction taking place in wet scrubbing using a {{chem|CaCO|3}} ([[limestone]]) slurry produces [[calcium sulfite]] ({{chem|CaSO|3}}) and may be expressed in the simplified dry form as:
:{{chem|CaCO|3}}{{sub|(s)}} + {{chem|SO|2}}{{sub|(g)}} → {{chem|CaSO|3}}{{sub|(s)}} + {{CO2}}{{sub|(g)}}
When wet scrubbing with a Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> ([[hydrated lime]]) slurry, the reaction also produces CaSO<sub>3</sub> ([[calcium sulfite]]) and may be expressed in the simplified dry form as:
:Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(s)}} + SO<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} → CaSO<sub>3</sub>{{sub|(s)}} + H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}}
When wet scrubbing with a Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub> ([[magnesium hydroxide]]) slurry, the reaction produces MgSO<sub>3</sub> ([[magnesium sulfite]]) and may be expressed in the simplified dry form as:
:Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(s)}} + SO<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} → MgSO<sub>3</sub>{{sub|(s)}} + H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}}
To partially offset the cost of the FGD installation, some designs, particularly dry sorbent injection systems, further oxidize the CaSO<sub>3</sub> (calcium sulfite) to produce marketable CaSO<sub>4</sub>-2H<sub>2</sub>O ([[gypsum]]) that can be of high enough quality to use in [[wallboard]] and other products. The process by which this synthetic gypsum is created is also known as forced oxidation:
:CaSO<sub>3</sub>{{sub|(aq)}} + 2H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}} + ½O<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} → CaSO<sub>4</sub> · 2H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(s)}}
A natural alkaline usable to absorb SO<sub>2</sub> is seawater. The {{chem|SO|2}} is absorbed in the water, and when oxygen is added reacts to form sulfate ions SO<sub>4</sub>- and free H<sup>+</sup>. The surplus of H<sup>+</sup> is offset by the carbonates in seawater pushing the carbonate equilibrium to release {{CO2}} gas:
:SO<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} + H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}} + ½O<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} → SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>{{sub|(aq)}} + 2H<sup>+</sup>
:HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> + H<sup>+</sup> → H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}} + CO<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}}
In industry [[Caustic soda|caustic]] (NaOH) is often used to scrub {{chem|SO|2}}, producing [[sodium sulfite]]:
:2NaOH{{sub|(aq)}} + SO<sub>2</sub>{{sub|(g)}} → Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>{{sub|(aq)}} + H<sub>2</sub>O{{sub|(l)}}<ref name="RJC">[http://rasayanjournal.co.in/vol-3/issue-2/23.pdf] REMOVAL OF SULPHUR DIOXIDE FROM FLUE GASES IN THERMAL PLANTS</ref>
==== Types of wet scrubbers used in FGD ==== To promote maximum [[Liquid-to-gas ratio|gas–liquid surface area]] and residence time, a number of wet scrubber designs have been used, including spray towers, venturis, plate towers, and mobile [[packed bed]]s. Because of scale buildup, plugging, or erosion, which affect FGD dependability and absorber efficiency, the trend is to use simple scrubbers such as spray towers instead of more complicated ones. The configuration of the tower may be vertical or horizontal, and flue gas can flow cocurrently, countercurrently, or crosscurrently with respect to the liquid. The chief drawback of spray towers is that they require a higher liquid-to-gas ratio requirement for equivalent {{chem|SO|2}} removal than other absorber designs.
FGD scrubbers produce a scaling wastewater that requires treatment to meet discharge regulations.<ref name="EPA reg">U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Washington, D.C. [http://www2.epa.gov/eg/steam-electric-power-generating-effluent-guidelines-2015-final-rule "Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category."] Final Rule. 2015-09-30.</ref> However, technological advancements in [[ion exchange membranes]] and [[electrodialysis]] systems has enabled high-efficiency treatment of FGD wastewater to meet recent EPA discharge limits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lowering Cost and Waste in Flue Gas Desulfurization Wastewater Treatment|url=http://www.powermag.com/lowering-cost-waste-flue-gas-desulfurization-wastewater-treatment/|website=Power Mag|publisher=Electric Power|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> The treatment approach is similar for other highly scaling industrial wastewaters.
=====Venturi-rod scrubbers===== {{main|venturi scrubber}} A [[venturi scrubber]] is a converging/diverging section of duct. The converging section accelerates the gas stream to high velocity. When the liquid stream is injected at the throat, which is the point of maximum velocity, the turbulence caused by the high gas velocity atomizes the liquid into small droplets, which creates the surface area necessary for mass transfer to take place. The higher the pressure drop in the venturi, the smaller the droplets and the higher the surface area. The penalty is in power consumption.
For simultaneous removal of {{chem|SO|2}} and fly ash, venturi scrubbers can be used. In fact, many of the industrial sodium-based throwaway systems are venturi scrubbers originally designed to remove particulate matter. These units were slightly modified to inject a sodium-based scrubbing liquor. Although removal of both particles and {{chem|SO|2}} in one vessel can be economic, the problems of high pressure drops and finding a scrubbing medium to remove heavy loadings of fly ash must be considered. However, in cases where the particle concentration is low, such as from oil-fired units, it can be more effective to remove particulate and {{chem|SO|2}} simultaneously.
=====Packed bed scrubbers===== A packed scrubber consists of a tower with packing material inside. This packing material can be in the shape of saddles, rings, or some highly specialized shapes designed to maximize the contact area between the dirty gas and liquid. Packed towers typically operate at much lower pressure drops than venturi scrubbers and are therefore cheaper to operate. They also typically offer higher {{chem|SO|2}} removal efficiency. The drawback is that they have a greater tendency to plug up if particles are present in excess in the exhaust air stream.
=====Spray towers===== {{main|spray tower}} A [[spray tower]] is the simplest type of scrubber. It consists of a tower with spray nozzles, which generate the droplets for surface contact. [[Spray tower]]s are typically used when circulating a slurry (see below). The high speed of a venturi would cause erosion problems, while a packed tower would plug up if it tried to circulate a slurry.
Counter-current packed towers are infrequently used because they have a tendency to become plugged by collected particles or to scale when [[lime (mineral)|lime]] or [[limestone]] scrubbing slurries are used.
==== Scrubbing reagent ====
As explained above, alkaline sorbents are used for scrubbing flue gases to remove SO<sub>2</sub>. Depending on the application, the two most important are [[Lime (mineral)|lime]] and [[sodium hydroxide]] (also known as [[caustic soda]]). Lime is typically used on large coal- or oil-fired boilers as found in power plants, as it is very much less expensive than caustic soda. The problem is that it results in a slurry being circulated through the scrubber instead of a solution. This makes it harder on the equipment. A spray tower is typically used for this application. The use of lime results in a slurry of calcium sulfite (CaSO<sub>3</sub>) that must be disposed of. Fortunately, calcium sulfite can be oxidized to produce by-product gypsum (CaSO<sub>4</sub> · 2H<sub>2</sub>O) which is marketable for use in the building products industry.
Caustic soda is limited to smaller combustion units because it is more expensive than lime, but it has the advantage that it forms a solution rather than a slurry. This makes it easier to operate. It produces a "[[spent caustic]]" solution of [[sodium sulfite]]/bisulfite (depending on the pH), or sodium sulfate that must be disposed of. This is not a problem in a [[kraft pulp]] mill for example, where this can be a source of makeup chemicals to the recovery cycle.
=== Scrubbing with sodium sulfite solution ===
It is possible to scrub [[sulfur dioxide]] by using a cold solution of [[sodium sulfite]]; this forms a sodium hydrogen sulfite solution. By heating this solution it is possible to reverse the reaction to form sulfur dioxide and the sodium sulfite solution. Since the sodium sulfite solution is not consumed, it is called a regenerative treatment. The application of this reaction is also known as the [[Wellman–Lord process]].
In some ways this can be thought of as being similar to the reversible [[liquid–liquid extraction]] of an [[inert gas]] such as [[xenon]] or [[radon]] (or some other solute which does not undergo a chemical change during the extraction) from water to another phase. While a chemical change does occur during the extraction of the sulfur dioxide from the gas mixture, it is the case that the extraction equilibrium is shifted by changing the temperature rather than by the use of a chemical reagent.
=== Gas phase oxidation followed by reaction with ammonia ===
A new, emerging flue gas desulfurization technology has been described by the [[IAEA]].<ref>[http://www-tc.iaea.org/tcweb/publications/factsheets/sheet16p.pdf IAEA Factsheet] about pilot plant in Poland.</ref> It is a [[radiation]] technology where an intense beam of [[electrons]] is fired into the flue gas at the same time as [[ammonia]] is added to the gas. The Chendu power plant in China started up such a flue gas desulfurization unit on a 100 MW scale in 1998. The Pomorzany power plant in Poland also started up a similar sized unit in 2003 and that plant removes both sulfur and nitrogen oxides. Both plants are reported to be operating successfully.<ref name=Wu>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.iaea.org/inis/collection/NCLCollectionStore/_Public/36/116/36116306.pdf |chapter=Electron beam application in gas waste treatment in China |last1=Haifeng |first1=Wu |publisher=INET Tsinghua University |location=Beijing, China |title=Proceedings of the FNCA 2002 workshop on application of electron accelerator}}</ref><ref name=IAEA>[http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Reports/Anrep2003/physical.pdf Section of IAEA 2003 Annual Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221100739/http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Reports/Anrep2003/physical.pdf |date=21 February 2007 }}</ref> However, the accelerator design principles and manufacturing quality need further improvement for continuous operation in industrial conditions.<ref>[http://www.ichtj.waw.pl/ichtj/nukleon/back/full/vol50_2005/v50s3p17f.pdf ''Application of ionizing radiation to environmental protection''] by A.G. Chmielewski, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland.</ref>
No [[radioactivity]] is required or created in the process. The electron beam is generated by a device similar to the [[electron gun]] in a TV set. This device is called an accelerator. This is an example of a radiation chemistry process<ref name=IAEA/> where the physical effects of radiation are used to process a substance.
The action of the electron beam is to promote the oxidation of sulfur dioxide to sulfur(VI) compounds. The ammonia reacts with the sulfur compounds thus formed to produce [[ammonium sulfate]], which can be used as a nitrogenous [[fertilizer]]. In addition, it can be used to lower the nitrogen oxide content of the flue gas. This method has attained industrial plant scale.<ref name=Wu/><ref>[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=20634234 ''Industrial Plant for Flue Gas Treatment with High Power Electron Accelerator''] by A.G. Chmielewski, Warsaw University of Technology, Poland.</ref>
==Facts and statistics== :''The information in this section was obtained from a US EPA published fact sheet.''<ref name=EPA>[http://www.epa.gov/ttn/catc/dir1/ffdg.pdf Air Pollution Control Fact Sheet] US EPA date coded 2003, accessed 24 June 2006</ref>
Flue gas desulfurization scrubbers have been applied to combustion units firing coal and oil that range in size from 5 MW to 1500 MW. [[Scottish Power]] are spending £400 million installing FGD at [[Longannet power station]], which has a capacity of over 2 GW. Dry scrubbers and spray scrubbers have generally been applied to units smaller than 300 MW.
FGD has been fitted by [[RWE npower]] at [[Aberthaw Power Station]] in south Wales using the seawater process and works successfully on the 1580MW plant.
Approximately 85% of the flue gas desulfurization units installed in the US are wet scrubbers, 12% are spray dry systems, and 3% are dry injection systems.
The highest {{chem|SO|2}} removal efficiencies (greater than 90%) are achieved by wet scrubbers and the lowest (less than 80%) by dry scrubbers. However, the newer designs for dry scrubbers are capable of achieving efficiencies in the order of 90%.
In spray drying and dry injection systems, the flue gas must first be cooled to about 10–20 °C above [[adiabatic]] [[Saturation (chemistry)|saturation]] to avoid wet solids deposition on downstream equipment and plugging of baghouses.
The capital, operating and maintenance costs per [[short ton]] of {{chem|SO|2}} removed (in 2001 US dollars) are:
*For wet scrubbers larger than 400 MW, the cost is $200 to $500 per ton *For wet scrubbers smaller than 400 MW, the cost is $500 to $5,000 per ton *For spray dry scrubbers larger than 200 MW, the cost is $150 to $300 per ton *For spray dry scrubbers smaller than 200 MW, the cost is $500 to $4,000 per ton
== Alternative methods of reducing sulfur dioxide emissions==
An alternative to removing [[sulfur]] from the flue gases after burning is to remove the sulfur from the fuel before or during combustion. [[Hydrodesulfurization]] of fuel has been used for treating [[fuel oil]]s before use. [[Fluidized bed combustion]] adds lime to the fuel during combustion. The lime reacts with the SO<sub>2</sub> to form [[sulfate]]s which become part of the [[Coal assay#Ash|ash]]. This elemental sulfur is then separated and finally recovered at the end of the process for further usage in, for example, agricultural products. Safety is one of the greatest benefits of this method, as the whole process takes place at [[atmospheric pressure]] and ambient temperature. This method has been developed by Paqell, a joint venture between [[Shell Global Solutions]] and Paques.<ref name=Paqell>[http://paqell.com/thiopaq/process-description/ THIOPAQ Oil & Gas process description and flow diagram] – official Paqell website</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Bride-Brook-Salt-Marsh-s.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A salt marsh]] In [[ecology]], a '''halosere''' is a [[Ecological succession|succession]] in a saline environment. An example of a halosere is a [[salt marsh]].
In a [[river]] [[estuary]], large amounts of [[silt]] are deposited by the ebbing [[tide]]s and inflowing rivers.
The earliest [[plant]] colonizers are [[algae]] and [[Zostera|eel grass]], which can tolerate submergence by the tide for most of the 12-hour cycle and which trap mud, causing it to accumulate. Two other colonizers are ''[[Salicornia]]'' and ''[[Spartina]]'', which are [[halophytes]], i.e. plants that can tolerate saline conditions. They grow on the inter-tidal [[mudflat]]s with a maximum of four hours' exposure to air every 12 hours.
''Spartina'' has long [[root]]s enabling it to trap more mud than the initial colonizing plants and ''Salicornia'', and so on. In most places this becomes dominant vegetation. The initial tidal flats receive new [[sediment]]s daily, are waterlogged to the exclusion of [[oxygen]], and have a high [[pH]] value.
The sward zone, in contrast, is inhabited by plants that can only tolerate a maximum of four hours submergence every day (24 hours). The dominant species there are [[sea lavender]] and other numerous types of [[grass]]es.
However, although the vegetation there tends to form a thick mat, it is not continuous. Hollows may remain where the seawater becomes trapped elaving, after evaporation, saltpans in which the salinity is too great for plants. As the tide ebbs, water draining off the land may be concentrated into [[stream|creeks]].
==See also== * [[Seral community]]

'''Hypernuclear Physics''' is the science of hypernuclei, or nuclei which fall under the category of [[hypernucleus]], and their constituents and properties. These nuclei are made of [[baryons]] which have at least one [[hyperon]], i.e. a three-quark particle having at least one [[strange quark]] in them.
The [[Hall C]]<ref>https://www.jlab.org/Hall-C/</ref> and [[Hall A]]<ref>https://www.jlab.org/research/hall-a</ref> of [[JLab]], or the [[US Jefferson National Laboratory]], in [[Newport News]], VA, is currently involved among other international laboratories in research on the hypernuclei.<ref>https://hallcweb.jlab.org/experiments/hks/rrc02-html/node2.html</ref>
References:
* https://books.google.com.sa/books?id=6gvJCgAAQBAJ&dq=EV+Hungerford+hypernuclei&source=gbs_navlinks_s * http://www.europhysicsnews.org/articles/epn/pdf/2002/05/epn02501.pdf * http://www.iaea.org/inis/collection/NCLCollectionStore/_Public/32/003/32003023.pdf * {{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0375947486905506 | doi=10.1016/0375-9474(86)90550-6 | volume=450 | title=Experiments on Σ− hypernuclei with in flight kaons | journal=Nuclear Physics A | pages=157–164| year=1986 | last1=Hungerford | first1=E.V. | bibcode=1986NuPhA.450..157H }} * https://panda.gsi.de/oldwww/db/papersDB/varenna_hungerford.pdf

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{More citations needed|date=January 2009}} {{Clear}} '''John Brinckerhoff "Brinck"[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/31/arts/brinck-jackson-86-dies-was-guru-of-the-landscape.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm Brinck Jackson, 86, Dies; Was Guru of the Landscape – New York Times] Jackson''', ''' J. B. Jackson''', (September 25, 1909, [[Dinard]], France – August 28, 1996, [[La Cienega, NM]]) was a writer, publisher, [[Teacher|instructor]], and [[sketch artist]] in [[landscape design]]. [[Herbert Muschamp]], architecture critic of the ''[[New York Times]],'' stated that J. B. Jackson was "America's greatest living writer on the forces that have shaped the land this nation occupies." He was influential in broadening the perspective on the "vernacular" landscape. ==Early life== Born in France to American parents, J. B. Jackson spent his early school years with them in Washington, D.C., and in Europe. At age 14 (1923) he was enrolled at the elite [[Institut Le Rosey]] in Rolle, [[Switzerland]], where he became fluent in both French and German. He savored an environment of mountains, meadows, and forests, but also absorbed the human face of the Swiss cities and cantons. He would later draw upon his travels abroad in writings, sketches, and watercolors. He attended preparatory schools in New England and spent summers on his uncle's farm in [[New Mexico]]."John Brinckerhoff Jackson," ''American National Biography Online'', consulted July 23, 2009 [http://www.anb.org/articles/14/14-01151.html] During the height of his career, Jackson lived just southwest of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]], near an historic property known as ''El Rancho de las Golondrinas'' (The Ranch of the Swallows). ==Education and early writings== Jackson's experiences in college were influential in his approach to the shaping of the landscape. He attended the Experimental College of the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]. Jackson gained an insight into architecture and planning from the social criticism of [[Lewis Mumford]] and [[Oswald Spengler]]'s revelation in ''[[Decline of the West]]'' that "landscapes reflected the culture of the people that were living there." In 1929 Jackson entered [[Harvard]]. His instructor Irving Babbitt was influential in Jackson's opposition to modernism. Jackson's taste for [[Baroque style]] and history began to blossom at this time. He believed that the zest of the Baroque style was the essence of the connection between humankind and nature. While attending Harvard, Jackson wrote articles for the ''[[Harvard Advocate]].'' His career of writing about the landscape began here. Following graduation from Harvard in 1932, Jackson took courses in architecture, writing, and drawing. Each would later serve as the bases for essays, lectures, and articles for his magazine, ''Landscape.'' He wandered through Europe in 1934 to 1935 studying Baroque style. While in Europe, Jackson began to write articles critical of [[Nazism]] and published them in ''[[The American Review (literary journal)|The American Review]]'' and ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]].'' His interest in politics began to be expressed in his works. In 1938, his novel, titled ''Saints in Summertime,'' was published. The book revealed the infiltration of Nazism and the soldiers' attraction to energy emanating from power. ==Military service== After briefly trying his hand at ranching in New Mexico, Jackson enlisted in the army, in 1940. As an officer during war, he studied books to gain insight on the geography of the location. He deciphered code, studied maps, and learned the terrain. He read books by French geographers—[[Pierre Deffontaines]], [[Paul Vidal de la Blache]], and [[Albert Demangeon]]. It was at this time that he developed his interpretation that the shaping and devastation of the landscape came from the necessities for human existence. Jackson believed that human history brought about human geography. The landscape was the product of humankind's effort to "recreate heaven on earth". As the war ended, Jackson began to contemplate publishing a magazine of geography. ==''Landscape'' magazine== In the spring of 1951, he published the first issue of ''[[Landscape (magazine)|Landscape]],'' with the subtitle "Human Geography of the Southwest;" this was later dropped. Jackson served as the magazine's publisher and editor until 1968. At first, Jackson argued, quite literally, for a lofty – an airborne – view of the world, reveling in the perspective of aerial photographs. But Jackson's work, which dominated the first five issues of the magazine, was grounded in what he would later call the vernacular: an interest in the commonplace or everyday landscape. Jackson expressed an innate confidence in the ability of people of small means to make significant changes in their surroundings. In an opening essay, ''The Need of Being Versed in Country Things,'' Jackson states that "It is from the air that the true relationship between the natural and the human landscape is first clearly revealed. The peaks and canyons lose much of their impressiveness when seen from above. What catches our eye and arouses our interest is not the sandy washes and the naked rocks, but the evidences of man." His writings allowed him to raise questions and present controversial statements especially in reference to humans and their role in shaping the landscape. Jackson's collected essays have been published in seven books, in addition to ''A Sense of Place, a Sense of Time,'' which won the 1995 [[International PEN|PEN]] prize for essays. ==Teaching== Jackson was influential in the lives of many students, colleagues, admirers, and friends. He taught landscape history courses as adjunct professor at Harvard University's [[Graduate School of Design]] beginning in 1969{{cite book|author=John Brinckerhoff Jackson|editor= [[Helen Lefkowitz Horowitz]] |title=Landscape in Sight: Looking at America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cRddYSJCEBEC|year=1997|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-08074-2}} and at the College of Environmental Design and the Department of Geography at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He ended teaching classes in the late 1970s. Since then he has given lectures, especially on themes pertaining to urban issues. Jackson states that "We are not spectators; all human landscape is not a work of art." He felt strongly that the purpose of landscape is to provide a place for living and working and leisure. The [[Association of American Geographers]] established a Jackson Prize, to "reward American geographers who write books about the United States which convey the insights of professional geography in language that is interesting and attractive to a lay audience."{{cite web |url=http://www.aag.org/Grantsawards/Jacksonprize.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051221211748/http://www.aag.org/Grantsawards/Jacksonprize.html |archivedate=December 21, 2005 |df=mdy-all }} ==Cultural Landscapes Studies== As a scholar, historian and writer, John B. Jackson greatly influenced the development and trajectory of contemporary cultural landscape studies in America. In the introduction to ''Everyday America: Cultural Landscape Studies after J.B. Jackson'' (2003), editors Chris Wilson and Paul Groth note that the term '[[cultural landscape]]' rarely appeared in print prior to the 1950s. But between 1959 and 1990, they note, writers across disciplines have come to realize the importance of the built environment.
"More surprising," they claim, "was the discovery of everyday built spaces as significant evidence of social groups, power relations and culture by historians, American studies scholars, literary critics, and a growing number of anthropologists, sociologists and social theorists." It is a "way of thinking," they continue, with "inherent contradictions and multiple approaches.""Introduction," ''Everyday America: Cultural Landscape Studies after J.B. Jackson'' (2003), ed. Chris Wilson and Paul Groth
The history of landscape study and, more broadly, place and regional studies, illustrates the convergences with some of the histories here, both across discipline and nation. In the United States a popular fascination with vibrant architecture, communities, and landscapes of everyday America has been expressed by writers ranging from [[Walt Whitman]] to [[Mark Twain]], and by painter [[Winslow Homer]] through early-twentieth artists of common landscapes. The [[New Deal]] writers and painters explored a strong regionalist theme, which was also connected to the architectural and urban criticism of [[Lewis Mumford]]. The concern for environmental degradation caused by human activities was another American theme, spurred particularly by the Vermont writer [[George Perkins Marsh]]. Comparison of American trends to cultural landscape studies in other places is illuminating. Wilson and Groth write that German cultural landscape studies were primarily based on scientific categorizations of regions and settlements, with strong cross-disciplinary ties to geology and economic analysis. Historical accounts of landscape influenced British cultural studies, but the study of cultural landscapes also was strongly based on field observation and map interpretations. In France, the emphasis on unique culture and geography shaped the field, especially in ideas of ''genre de vie'' (ways of life) and ''pays'' (social regions), ideas that have had particular resonance in American landscape studies. "By World War II," the editors remark, "each French region had its own well-written guidebooks to local physical and social landscapes" (4). Geographer [[Carl Sauer]], who had studied in Germany and had long tenure as the chair of the Geography department at Berkeley, in 1925 wrote the now classic definition of a cultural landscape: "The cultural landscape is fashioned from the natural landscape by a cultural group. Culture is the agent, the natural area is the medium, and cultural landscape is the result." ==Quotes== "The older I grow and the longer I look at landscapes and seek to understand them, the more convinced I am that their beauty is not simply an aspect but their very essence and that that beauty derives from the human presence." "Let us hope that the merits and charm of the highway strip are not so obscure but they will be accepted by a wider public." "The bicycle had, and still has, a humane, almost classical moderation in the kind of pleasure it offers. It is the kind of machine that a Hellenistic Greek might have invented and ridden. It does no violence to our normal reactions: It does not pretend to free us from our normal environment." "The way a city grows, the direction in which it spreads, is a factor not so much of zoning or real estate activity or land values but of highways." "Ruins provide the incentive for restoration, and for a return to origins. There has to be an interim of death or rejection before there can be renewal and reform." ==Published works== Jackson's published works include: * ''Landscapes: Selected Writings of J. B. Jackson'' (1970) * ''American Space: The Centennial Years, 1865–1876'' (1972) * ''The Interpretation of Ordinary Landscapes: Geographical Essays'' edited with [[D. W. Meinig]] (1979) * ''The Necessity for Ruins and Other Topics'' (1980) * ''Discovering the Vernacular Landscape'' (1984) * ''A Sense of Place, a Sense of Time'' (1994) * ''Landscape in Sight: Looking at America'' (1997) ==Awards== John Brinckerhoff Jackson received the [[PEN/Diamonstein-Spielvogel Award for the Art of the Essay]] for ''A Sense of Place, a Sense of Time'' in 1995. J.B. Jackson received the Silver Star for exemplary service in WWII. ==References== == External links == * [https://rmoa.unm.edu/docviewer.php?docId=nmu1mss633bc.xml Inventory of the J.B. Jackson Papers, 1808-1996] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jackson, J. B.}} [[Category:1909 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:American architecture writers]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:American garden writers]] [[Category:American landscape and garden designers]] [[Category:American landscape architects]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Design faculty]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:PEN/Diamonstein-Spielvogel Award winners]] [[Category:Rome Prize winners]] [[Category:Writers from Santa Fe, New Mexico]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Harvard Advocate alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Institut Le Rosey]] [[Category:American nature writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]]

{{Infobox ecoregion | name = Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe | image = India north.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe near [[Ladakh]], [[India]] <!-- *** Country etc. *** --> | country = [[India]] | country1 = [[China]] | country2 = [[Afghanistan]] | country3 = [[Pakistan]] | border = [[Pamir alpine desert and tundra]] | border1 = [[North Tibetan Plateau-Kunlun Mountains and alpine desert]] | border2 = [[Central Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe]] | border3 = [[Western Himalayan alpine shrub and meadows]] | border4 = [[Northwestern Himalayan alpine shrub and meadows]] | border5 = [[Paropamisus xeric woodlands]] <!-- *** Free fields *** --> | bird_species = 172<ref name = "Atlas"> {{cite book |last1 = Hoekstra |first1 = J. M. |last2 = Molnar |first2 = J. L. |last3 = Jennings |first3 = M. |last4 = Revenga |first4 = C. |last5 = Spalding |first5 = M. D. |last6 = Boucher |first6 = T. M. |last7 = Robertson |first7 = J. C. |last8 = Heibel |first8 = T. J. |last9 = Ellison |first9 = K. |title = The Atlas of Global Conservation: Changes, Challenges, and Opportunities to Make a Difference |publisher = [[University of California Press]] |editor1-last = Molnar |editor1-first = J. L. |year = 2010 |isbn = 978-0-520-26256-0 |url=http://www.nature.org/multimedia/maps/ }}</ref> | mammal_species = 45<ref name = "Atlas"/> | habitat_loss = 1.4065 | habitat_loss_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | protected = 18.28 | protected_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | area = 143300 | biome = [[Montane grasslands and shrublands]] | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = }}
The '''Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe''' is a [[montane grasslands and shrublands]] [[terrestrial ecoregion|ecoregion]] found in parts of [[Pakistan]], [[China]], [[Afghanistan]], and [[India]].
==Setting== The Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe is an area of high-elevation grasslands covering {{convert|143300|sqkm|mi2}}. It is centered on the [[Karakoram]] Range, west of the [[Himalaya Range]]. It also includes nearby ranges, such as the [[Ladakh Range]].
==Climate== The mean annual precipitation in the ecoregion varies from {{convert|200|to|900|mm|in}}, 90 percent in the form of snow.
==Flora== [[File:Deosai Plateau 2.jpg|thumb|[[Deosai National Park]] in [[Pakistan]].]] Most of this ecoregion consists of grasslands and [[herbaceous plant]]s. Protected slopes and ravines contains ''[[Salix denticulata]], [[Mertensia tibetica]], [[Potentilla desertorum]], [[Juniperus polycarpus]], [[Polygonum viviparum]], [[Berberis pachyacantha]], [[Rosa webbiana]]'', and ''[[Spiraea lycoides]]''. Where vegetation ceases to grow, around {{convert|4500|m|ft}}, are found ''[[Delphinium cashmerianum]], [[Glechoma tibetica]], [[Silene longicarpophora]], [[Potentilla fruticosa]]'', and ''[[Nepeta]]'' spp.
Shrublands and woodlands are found in valley bottoms. These include ''[[Hippophae rhamnoides]], [[Myricaria elegans]], [[Salix viminalis]], [[Capparis spinosa]], [[Tribulus terrestris]], [[Pegamum harmala]], [[Sophora alopecuroides]]'', and ''[[Lycium ruthenicum]]''. A few remnant steppe forests of ''[[Juniperus macropoda]]'' and ''[[Juniperus indica]]'' are still found here.
==Fauna== Sheep in this ecoregion include the [[Ovis ammon polii|Marco Polo sheep]], [[Ovis ammon hodgsoni|Tibetan argali]], and [[Ovis orientalis vignei|urial]]. Goats include the [[Capra falconeri|markhor]] and [[Capra ibex|ibex]].
The sheep and goats, as well as smaller mammals, make this ecoregion excellent habitat for the [[Uncia uncia|snow leopard]].
Both the [[Ursus arctos|brown bear]] and [[Selenarctos thibetanus|Himalayan black bear]] are found here.
Bird species richness is low. Common birds include [[Phoenicurus erythrogaster|Guldenstadt's redstart]], [[Lophophorus impejanus|Himalayan monal]], [[Carpodacus|rosefinches]], [[Bird of prey|raptors]], and [[vultures]].
==Conservation== Much of the montane habitat in this ecoregion lies in protected areas. These include *[[Hemis National Park]] *[[Khunjerab National Park]] *[[Deosai National Park]]
==See also== *[[List of ecoregions in India]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe|id=pa1006}}

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Conus'' species}} This '''list of ''Conus'' species''' is a listing of [[species]] in the genus ''[[Conus]]'', a [[genus]] of [[sea snail]]s, specifically [[cone snail]]s, [[marine (ocean)|marine]] [[gastropod]] [[mollusk]]s in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Conidae]].<ref name="WoRMS">{{WRMS species|137813|''Conus'' Linnaeus, 1758||20 May 2010}}</ref>
For many years, all of the [[cone snails]] were placed in the genus ''Conus''. More recently a large number of species have been moved to other genera.
This list with about 800 accepted species relies on the taxonomy used in the [[World Register of Marine Species]] and the publication in 2015 by Puillandre N., Duda T.F., Meyer C., Olivera B.M. & Bouchet P. (2015). ''One, four or 100 genera? A new classification of the cone snails.'' Journal of Molluscan Studies. 81: 1-23 <ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1093/mollus/eyu055 | volume=81 | title=One, four or 100 genera? A new classification of the cone snails | year=2014 | journal=Journal of Molluscan Studies | pages=1–23 | author=Puillandre N| pmc=4541476 }}</ref>

This is a '''list of NGC objects 5001–6000''' from the [[New General Catalogue]] (NGC). The [[astronomical catalog]]ue is composed mainly of [[star cluster]]s, [[nebula]]e, and [[galaxies]]. Other objects in the catalogue can be found in the other subpages of the [[list of NGC objects]]. The constellation information in these tables is taken from ''The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer'', {{cite book |author=R. W. Sinnott, editor |title=The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer |date=1988 |publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-933346-51-4 }} which was accessed using the "VizieR Service".{{cite web |url=http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR |title=VizieR Service |work=Strasbourg astronomical Data Center |accessdate=18 August 2015}} Galaxy types are identified using the ''NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database''.{{cite web |url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ |title=NED |work=NED–NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database |accessdate=18 August 2015}} The other data of these tables are from the [[SIMBAD Astronomical Database]]{{cite web |url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/ |title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database |work=Strasbourg astronomical Data Center |accessdate=18 August 2015}} unless otherwise stated. ==5001–5100== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" ! revision.comment: Removing notice of move discussion
revision.text:
The '''list of North Carolina hurricanes''' between 1950 and 1979 encompasses 79 [[tropical cyclone|tropical]] or [[subtropical cyclone]]s that affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[North Carolina]]. Collectively, cyclones in North Carolina during that time period resulted in 37 total fatalities during the period, as well as about $3 billion in damage in 2008 [[United States dollar|USD]]. A cyclone affected the state in every year during the three decades, and in three seasons a total of five cyclones impacted the state. The strongest hurricane to hit the state during the time period was [[Hurricane Hazel]], which struck the state as a [[List of Category 4 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 4 hurricane]] on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]]. Hazel was both the costliest and deadliest cyclone during the period, causing over $1 billion in damage (2008 USD) and 19 deaths. Most storms affected the state in September, though cyclones impacted the state between May and October.
==1950s== [[Image:Hurricane Connie Radar.gif|right|thumb|200px|Radar image of [[Hurricane Connie]] near North Carolina]] *August 20, 1950 – [[Hurricane Able (1950)|Hurricane Able]] brushes the [[Outer Banks]] with light winds and rough waves.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1950-08-21|title=North Carolina's East Coast Areas Return to Normal|accessdate=2008-02-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=44599081_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=44599081_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-23|df=}}</ref> *September 7, 1950 – Former [[Hurricane Easy (1950)|Hurricane Easy]] weakens to tropical depression status over [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], bringing heavy rainfall to North Carolina which peaks at {{convert|9.14|in|mm|0}} in [[Yancey County, North Carolina|Yancey County]].{{Tropical Cyclone Rainfall in the Southeastern United States}} *September 11, 1950 – [[Hurricane Dog (1950)|Hurricane Dog]] skirts the coastline as it remains well offshore.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1950-09-11|title=Hurricane Off North Carolina; Another On Way|accessdate=2008-02-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=92106503_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=92106503_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-23|df=}}</ref> *May 21, 1951 – [[Hurricane Able (1951)|Hurricane Able]] produces high surf along the coastline.<ref name="ap521">{{cite news|author=Associated Press|date=1951-05-21|title=Coast Alerted for Hurricane|accessdate=2008-02-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=7985764&firstvisit=true&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=7985764&firstvisit=true&currentResult=6&currentPage=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23}}</ref> *October 4, 1951 – [[Hurricane How (1951)|Hurricane How]] brushes the coastline with heavy surf.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1951-10-04|title=Giant Hurricane Heads Into the Open Atlantic|accessdate=2008-02-08|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=100998886_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=100998886_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=1&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-23|df=}}</ref> *August 31, 1952 – [[Hurricane Able (1952)|Tropical Storm Able]] crosses the center portion of the state, causing moderate precipitation and stream flooding.<ref name="nc"/> *August 14, 1953 – [[Hurricane Barbara (1953)|Hurricane Barbara]] moves ashore near [[Morehead City, North Carolina|Morehead City]] with {{convert|90|mph|km/h|0}} wind gusts and rainfall, which causes about $1.1 million in damage (1953 USD, $8.9 million 2008 USD), mostly from crop damage; one person drowned due to the storm.<ref name="nc"/> *September 28, 1953 – Moisture from former [[Hurricane Florence (1953)|Hurricane Florence]] brings moderate rainfall to the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1953-09-28|title=Heavy Rains Hit Sections of Southeast|accessdate=2008-02-09|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=5036587_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=8&currentPage=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=5036587_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=8&currentPage=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23}}</ref> *August 30, 1954 – [[Hurricane Carol]] passes just east of the state, producing {{convert|100|mph|km/h|0}} wind gusts and rough waves along the Outer Banks; damage is minor, largely limited to crop damage.<ref name="nc"/> *September 10, 1954 – Strong waves from [[Hurricane Edna]] cause widespread but minor damage to the Outer Banks.<ref name="nc"/> *October 15, 1954 – [[Hurricane Hazel]] moves ashore near the South Carolina/North Carolina border as a [[List of Category 4 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 4]] hurricane,<ref name="chron">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2006|title=Chronological List of All Hurricanes which Affected the Continental United States: 1851-2005|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/ushurrlist.htm}}</ref> destroying 15,000 buildings and damaging 39,000 more. Damage is greatest in [[Brunswick County, North Carolina|Brunswick County]], where great coastal damage occurs due to a powerful storm tide. Considered the most destructive hurricane to affect the state at the time, the hurricane causes an estimated damage total of $136 million (1954 USD, $1.09 billion 2008 USD). Hurricane Hazel injures 200 and kills 19 people in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=NOAA Coastal Services Center |year=1999 |title=New Hanover County, North Carolina Case Study on Hurricane Hazel |accessdate=2008-02-16 |url=http://www.csc.noaa.gov/products/nchaz/htm/hazel.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211185038/http://www.csc.noaa.gov/products/nchaz/htm/hazel.htm |archivedate=2008-02-11 |df= }}</ref> *August 12, 1955 – [[Hurricane Connie]] strikes the Outer Banks and produces severe beach erosion.<ref name="1955mwr">{{cite web|author=Dunn, Davis, and Moore|year=1955|title=Hurricanes of 1955|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/083/mwr-083-12-0315.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> It drops up to {{convert|12|in|mm|0}} of precipitation, which floods large areas of crop lands. No deaths are reported in the state,<ref name="nc"/> and damage accrues to $80 million (1955 USD, $640 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1955mwr"/> *August 17, 1955 – [[Hurricane Diane]] makes landfall near Wilmington, producing further beach erosion and flooding just five days after the previous hurricane. Wind damage is light, and no fatalities or injuries occur in the state.<ref name="nc"/> *September 19, 1955 – Moving ashore near Morehead City, [[Hurricane Ione]] drops heavy rainfall which peaks at {{convert|16.6|in|mm|0}} near [[Maysville, North Carolina|Maysville]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Ione|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ione1955.html}}</ref> The combination of high tides and rainfall leaves large portions of eastern North Carolina flooded, including large areas of crop lands. The hurricane kills seven, of which two indirectly due to traffic accidents, and damage totals to $88 million (1955 USD, $708 million 2008 USD).<ref name="nc"/> *August 16, 1956 – [[Hurricane Betsy (1956)|Hurricane Betsy]] brushes the coastline with rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1956-08-17|title=Rain Postpones Junior Tourney|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=77924528_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=77924528_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=4&currentPage=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23}}</ref> *September 8, 1956 – The interaction between a high pressure system and [[1956 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Carla|Tropical Storm Carla]] produces moderate winds along the coastline.<ref name="1956mwr">{{cite web|author=Dunn, Davis, and Moore|year=1956|title=Hurricane Season of 1956|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-16|format=PDF|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/084/mwr-084-12-0436.pdf}}</ref> *September 26, 1956 – The [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical remains]] of [[Hurricane Flossy (1956)|Hurricane Flossy]] produce moderate rainfall across much of the state, which is beneficial after previous dry conditions.<ref name="nc"/> *October, 1956 – A [[1956 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|quasi-tropical storm]] passes over the Outer Banks.<ref name="1956mwr"/> *September 9, 1957 – The remnants of [[1957 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Debbie|Tropical Storm Debbie]] brings light rainfall to the state.<ref name="sep1957">{{cite web|author=Emanuel Ballenzweig|year=1957|title=The Weather and Circulation of September 1957|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/085/mwr-085-09-0315.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 18, 1957 – A weak tropical depression crosses the state.<ref name="sep1957"/> *August 28, 1958 – [[1958 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Daisy|Hurricane Daisy]] passes just offshore, producing light winds but little damage.<ref name="1958mwr">{{cite web|author=U.S. Weather Bureau|year=1958|title=The Hurricane Season of 1958|accessdate=2008-02-16|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/086/mwr-086-12-0477.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 27, 1958 – [[Hurricane Helene (1958)|Hurricane Helene]] parallels the coastline just offshore with wind gusts reaching {{convert|135|mph|km/h|0}}. The winds cause moderate structural and crop damage, totaling about $11 million (1958 USD, $82 million 2008 USD).<ref name="nc"/> *July 10, 1959 – [[Hurricane Cindy (1959)|Tropical Depression Cindy]] crosses through the state, producing heavy rainfall and some tornadoes.<ref name="1959mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn and Staff|year=1959|title=The Hurricane Season of 1959|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-17|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/087/mwr-087-12-0441.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 30, 1959 – Former [[Hurricane Gracie]] passes through the central portion of the state and causes moderate tides near the coastline, as well as heavy rainfall in the inland mountains region.<ref name="nc"/>
==1960s==
*July 29, 1960 – Crossing the eastern portion of the state, [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1960)|Tropical Storm Brenda]] produces locally heavy rainfall and gusty winds.<ref name="nc"/> *September 12, 1960 – [[Hurricane Donna]] moves across the Outer Banks, causing heavy damage from the combination of high winds and waves. Up to a distance of 50 miles (80 km) inland, strong winds down trees and crops,<ref name="nc"/> and damage in the state totals $56.5 million (1960 USD, $422 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1960mwr">{{cite web|author=Gordon E. Dunn|year=1961|title=The Hurricane Season of 1960|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-17|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/089/mwr-089-03-0099.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Across the state, over 100 people are injured, and eight people are killed, of which five directly.<ref name="nc"/> *September 14, 1961 – A [[1961 Atlantic hurricane season#Unnamed Tropical Storm|tropical storm]] strikes the state, though no serious damage is reported.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Fay|year=1962|title=Northbound Tropical Cyclone|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-17|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/089/mwr-089-03-0099.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 20, 1961 – [[Hurricane Esther (1961)|Hurricane Esther]] passes offshore with slightly above normal tides and light winds.<ref name="nc"/> *September 28, 1962 – [[1962 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Alma|Tropical Storm Alma]] attains hurricane status near the Outer Banks, though winds on land are minor, and little damage is reported.<ref name="nc"/> *October 12, 1962 – The interaction between [[1962 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Ella|Hurricane Ella]] and a high pressure system produces above normal tides and beach erosion along the coastline.<ref name="nc"/> *October, 1963 – [[Hurricane Ginny]] affects the coastline for about a week with rough winds, which cause severe beach erosion; the hurricane destroys one house, though overall damage was limited.<ref name="nc"/> *August 30, 1964 – Former [[Hurricane Cleo]] enters the state as a tropical depression, spawning several tornadoes and dropping heavy rainfall.<ref name="nc"/> *September 13, 1964 – Paralleling the coastline just offshore, [[Hurricane Dora|Tropical Storm Dora]] causes some beach erosion and precipitation.<ref name="nc"/> *September 21, 1964 – [[Hurricane Gladys (1964)|Hurricane Gladys]] causes high tides along the coastline.<ref name="nc"/> *October 5, 1964 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Hilda]] drop moderate to heavy precipitation across the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *October 16, 1964 – [[Hurricane Isbell (1964)|Hurricane Isbell]] makes landfall near Morehead City with gusty winds and locally heavy rainfall; damage is minor.<ref name="nc"/> *June 16, 1965 – A former [[1965 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|tropical storm]] crosses through the state.<ref name="1966mwr">{{cite web|author=Arnold Sugg|year=1966|title=The Hurricane Season of 1966|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-02-18|format=PDF|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/094/mwr-094-03-0183.pdf}}</ref> *September 12, 1965 – After becoming [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]] over the [[Ohio Valley]], the remnants of [[Hurricane Betsy]] bring light rainfall to the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *June 11, 1966 – [[Hurricane Alma (1966)|Hurricane Alma]] parallels the coastline offshore, producing above normal tides and moderate precipitation.<ref name="nc"/> *August 29, 1966 – Rough seas from [[Hurricane Faith]] cause four drownings along the coastline.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1966-09-02|title=Hurricane Faith|accessdate=2008-02-18|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=93877861_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=93877861_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archivedate=2016-01-23|df=}}</ref> *September 16, 1967 – [[Hurricane Doria (1967)|Tropical Storm Doria]] enters the state from the northeast with slightly above normal tides; damage is minor.<ref name="nc"/> *June 9, 1968 – Former [[Hurricane Abby (1968)|Hurricane Abby]] moves across much of the state, dropping moderate precipitation and spawning a tornado near Charlotte.<ref name="nc"/> *October 19, 1968 – [[Hurricane Gladys (1968)|Hurricane Gladys]] passes just offshore, bringing moderate to heavy rainfall across the state; the rainfall is beneficial due to previously dry conditions.<ref name="nc"/> *August 20, 1969 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Camille]] drop light rainfall across the western portion of the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 9, 1969 – [[Hurricane Gerda (1969)|Hurricane Gerda]] brushes the coastline with light winds and rainfall.<ref name="nc"/> *September 24, 1969 – A tropical depression brings light precipitation to much of the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *October 15, 1969 – Originally predicted to strike the Outer Banks, [[1969 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Kara|Hurricane Kara]] passes offshore, only affecting small craft.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=1969-10-15|title=Kara Turns Out to Sea|accessdate=2008-02-18|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=100288426_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=100288426_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=10|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23}}</ref>
==1970s== [[Image:Ginger damage.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Beach erosion on the [[Outer Banks]] from [[Hurricane Ginger (1971)|Hurricane Ginger]]]] *May 26, 1970 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Alma (1970)|Hurricane Alma]] cross the eastern portion of the state.{{Easy Hurdat}} *August 17, 1970 – An unnamed tropical depression moves across the [[Outer Banks]], bringing locally heavy rainfall and gusty winds.<ref>{{cite web|author=David B. Spiegler|year=1971|title=The Unnamed Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1970|publisher=U.S. Weather Service|accessdate=2008-01-31|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/099/mwr-099-12-0966.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 17, 1971 – A tropical depression moving through the southeastern United States drops up to {{convert|12|in|mm|0}} in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Raymond A. Green|year=1971|title=Weather and Circulation of August 1971|publisher=U.S. Weather Service|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-01-31|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/099/mwr-099-11-0889.pdf}}</ref> *August 27, 1971 – [[Tropical Storm Doria (1971)|Tropical Storm Doria]] makes [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] near [[Morehead City, North Carolina|Morehead City]], which causes mudslides from heavy rainfall but overall light damage.<ref name="nc">{{cite web|author=James E. Hudgins|year=2000|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting North Carolina since 1566 – An Historical Perspective|publisher=Blacksburg, Virginia National Weather Service|accessdate=2008-01-31|url=http://repository.wrclib.noaa.gov/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1002&context=nws_tech_memos |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070311045226/http://repository.wrclib.noaa.gov/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1002&context=nws_tech_memos |archivedate = 2007-03-11}}</ref> *September 12, 1971 – A tropical depression dissipates in the state after entering through [[South Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Neil Frank|year=1972|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1971|publisher=U.S. Weather Service|accessdate=2008-01-31|format=PDF|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/100/mwr-100-04-0268.pdf}}</ref> *September 19, 1971 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Edith (1971)|Hurricane Edith]] drop moderate precipitation in the western portion of the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 30, 1971 – [[Hurricane Ginger (1971)|Hurricane Ginger]] makes landfall near [[Atlantic Beach, North Carolina|Atlantic Beach]] and slowly moves across the state, dropping heavy rainfall peaking at {{convert|15.6|in|mm|0}} at [[Bodie Island]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> The precipitation causes severe crop damage totalling $10 million (1971 USD, $53 million 2008 USD).<ref name="nc"/> *May 26, 1972 – [[Subtropical Storm Alpha (1972)|Subtropical Storm Alpha]] attains gale-force winds to the southeast of the Outer Banks after dropping {{convert|6.97|in|mm|0}} of rainfall at [[Ocracoke, North Carolina|Ocracoke]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> *June 21, 1972 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Agnes]] re-attain tropical storm status over the northeastern portion of the state. The interaction with a low to its west results in heavy rainfall of up to {{convert|10.6|in|mm|0}} on [[Mount Mitchell (North Carolina)|Mount Mitchell]], which causes record river flooding and severe crop damage.<ref name="nc"/> Throughout the state, Agnes causes two deaths and $6.56 million in damage (1972 USD, $33.8 million 2008 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center|year=1972|title=U.S. Deaths and Damage Attributed to Hurricane Agnes|accessdate=2008-02-01|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1972-prelim/agnes/prelim09.gif}}</ref> *July 12, 1972 – A tropical depression moves ashore near the South Carolina/North Carolina border.<ref>{{cite web|author=Neil Frank|year=1973|title=Atlantic Tropical Systems of 1972|publisher=U.S. Weather Service|accessdate=2008-02-01|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/101/mwr-101-04-0334.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 31, 1972 – Attaining tropical storm status to the southeast of the state, [[Tropical Storm Carrie (1972)|Tropical Storm Carrie]] drops light precipitation along the coastline.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 15, 1972 – The remnants of [[1972 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Dawn|Hurricane Dawn]] dissipate offshore of South Carolina, dropping very light rainfall in North Carolina.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *October 24, 1973 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Gilda (1973)|Tropical Depression Gilda]] reform into a large [[subtropical cyclone]], which produces gale-force winds and beach erosion along the Outer Banks.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Paul Hebert|author2=Neil Frank|lastauthoramp=yes|year=1974|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1973|publisher=U.S. Weather Service|accessdate=2008-02-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-280.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20080202131419/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-280.pdf |archivedate=2008-02-02|df=}} </ref> *June 26, 1974 – The first [[Subtropical Storm One (1974)|subtropical storm]] of the season brushes the coastline with light rainfall.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *June 26, 1974 – A tropical depression transitions into an [[extratropical cyclone]], with its remnants dropping moderate precipitation near the coastline.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *October 8, 1974 – The fourth [[1974 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm Four|subtropical storm]] of the season produces rainfall in the eastern portion of the state as it parallels offshore.<ref name="WPCSE"/> [[Image:Hurricane Belle.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Hurricane Belle (1976)|Hurricane Belle]] to the southeast of the state]] *June 29, 1975 – A tropical depression intensifies into [[Tropical Storm Amy (1975)|Tropical Storm Amy]], after brushing the Outer Banks with light rainfall.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 24, 1975 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Eloise]] become extratropical over eastern [[Tennessee]], spawning a few tornadoes and dropping moderate precipitation across western North Carolina.<ref name="WPCSE"/><ref>{{cite web|author=David Carragan|title=Hurricane Eloise — Super 70's|accessdate=2008-02-02|url=http://www.super70s.com/Super70s/Tech/Nature/Disasters/Hurricanes/75Sept27-Eloise.asp}}</ref> *October 2, 1975 – [[Hurricane Gladys (1975)|Hurricane Gladys]] threatens the Outer Banks with rough waves, but remains well offshore.<ref>{{cite web|author=United Press International|date=1975-10-02|title=Hurricane Gladys Turns from Land|accessdate=2008-02-02|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=76261568_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=5&currentPage=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=76261568_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=5&currentPage=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 27, 1975 – [[Tropical Storm Hallie (1975)|Tropical Storm Hallie]] brushes the coastline with light precipitation.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *May 24, 1976 – [[1976 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm One|Subtropical Storm One]] drops light rainfall near the coastline as parallels the coastline.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *August 9, 1976 – [[Hurricane Belle (1976)|Hurricane Belle]] passes just offshore, producing strong wind gusts and a moderate storm tide that left areas flooded.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles Lawrence|year=1977|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1976|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2008-02-02|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/105/4/pdf/i1520-0493-105-4-497.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20080202094118/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/105/4/pdf/i1520-0493-105-4-497.pdf |archivedate=2008-02-02|df=}} </ref><ref>{{cite web|date=1976-08-09|title=First Hurricane of the Season Nears No. Carolina Coast|author=United Press International|accessdate=2008-02-02|url=http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=55229114_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123005006/http://www.thehurricanearchive.com/Viewer.aspx?img=55229114_clean&firstvisit=true&src=search&currentResult=0&currentPage=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-01-23}}</ref> *August 20, 1976 – [[Tropical Storm Dottie]] moves ashore along South Carolina, causing beach erosion and locally heavy rainfall in southern North Carolina.<ref name="nc"/> *September 15, 1976 – A [[1976 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm Three|subtropical depression]] brings moderate rainfall as it crosses the state.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 6, 1977 – The tropical depression that later becomes [[1977 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Clara|Hurricane Clara]] brushes the coastline with light precipitation.<ref name="WPCSE"/> *September 9, 1977 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Babe (1977)|Hurricane Babe]] near the South Carolina/North Carolina border, producing rainfall across the entire state that peaks at {{convert|8.99|in|mm|0}} in [[Transylvania County, North Carolina|Transylvania County]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> *August 29, 1978 – [[Tropical Storm Debra (1978)|Tropical Storm Debra]] strikes [[Louisiana]], with its remnants producing rainfall in the northern North Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Debra|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-02-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/debra1978.html}}</ref> *September 2, 1978 – [[Hurricane Ella (1978)|Hurricane Ella]] turns northeastward well offshore after threatening the Outer Banks; it causes some beach erosion and loss of tourism during the traditionally busy [[Labor Day|Labor Day Weekend]].<ref name="nc"/> *July 15, 1979 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Bob (1979)|Hurricane Bob]] cross the eastern portion of the state from north to south, exiting into the Atlantic Ocean near Morehead City after dropping light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Bob|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-02-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/bob1979.html}}</ref> *July 31, 1979 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Claudette (1979)|Tropical Storm Claudette]] dissipate after producing light rainfall in the northeastern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Claudette|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-02-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/claudette1979.html}}</ref> *September 5, 1979 – Former [[Hurricane David]] crosses the central portion of the state, dropping heavy rainfall peaking at {{convert|15.4|in|mm|0}} in [[New Holland, North Carolina|New Holland]].<ref name="WPCSE"/> The storm causes flooding and beach erosion, though no significant damage is reported.<ref name="nc"/> *September 14, 1979 – Former [[Hurricane Frederic]] passes through eastern Tennessee, and drops locally moderate precipitation in western North Carolina.<ref>{{cite book|author=Roth, David M|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Frederic|author2=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-02-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/frederic1979.html}}</ref>
==Monthly statistics== {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting North Carolina | data_max = 35 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label5 = May | data5 = 4 | label6 = June | data6 = 7 | label7 = July | data7 = 5 | label8 = August | data8 = 18 | label9 = September | data9 = 32 | label10 = October | data10 = 13 }}
==Deadly storms== The table lists hurricanes by death tolls. Direct deaths are those that are directly caused by the storm passage, such as drownings or deaths from being struck by windblown objects. Indirect deaths are those that are related to the storm, but not directly from its storm effects. <center> {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Name ! Year ! Number of deaths |- | [[Hurricane Hazel|Hazel]] || 1954 || |{{sort|6|19 direct}} |- | [[Hurricane Donna|Donna]] || 1960 || {{sort|5|5 direct (3 indirect)}} |- | [[Hurricane Ione|Ione]] || 1955 || {{sort|4|5 direct (2 indirect)}} |- | [[Hurricane Faith|Faith]] || 1966 || {{sort|3|4 direct}} |- | [[Hurricane Agnes|Agnes]] || 1972 || {{sort|2|2 direct}} |- | [[Hurricane Barbara (1953)|Barbara]] || 1953 || {{sort|1|1 direct}} |- |} </center>
